abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for both
            the HIV/AIDS Response Project (SHARP) and the Health Sector
            Reconstruction and Development Project (HSRDP) describes the
            comprehensive waste management plan made to counter
            anticipated negative environmental impacts. Appropriate
            design, sites and operation of sanitary landfills, leachate
            treatment and control, and water quality testing will reduce
            the risk of drinking water contamination. High temperature
            incineration, installation of flue gas cleaning devices, air
            quality testing, and non-incineration of materials
            containing chlorine or heavy metals will prevent release of
            pollutants into the air. Provision and ensuring the routine
            use of protective clothing, staff training, and teaching
            first aid will reduce the occurrence of occupational
            hazards. Limiting access to disposal sites, fencing of
            disposal sites, separating cells for medical wastes, and
            sensitizing the public through the media, particularly
            radio, television, posters, leaflets, newspapers, etc., will
            minimize disease transmission. Furthermore, all health care
            facilities will be equipped with appropriate equipment,
            materials, and facilities for collecting, managing, and
            transporting medical waste. Incinerators will be built and
            adapted for use in health facilities. Infectious hospital
            waste will be disposed of in sanitary landfills with set precautions.
